byline.contributor: Hawes Spencer reported from Blacksburg, Sheryl Gay Stolberg from Washington, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Alain Delaquérière contributed research.
byline.original: By HAWES SPENCER, SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Virginia Tech students Natalie M Keepers and David Eisenhauer are arrested and being held without bond in killing of Virginia teenager Nicole Madison Lovell; authorities have not said what, if any, role social media may have played in killing, but Lovell’s electronic communications have set off fresh concerns about dangers to young people who seek liaisons on social media.
lead_paragraph: The arrest of two Virginia Tech students in the abduction and murder of a 13-year-old girl who posted on a Facebook group called Teen Dating and Flirting has set off fresh concerns about the dangers of young people who seek liaisons on social media.

headline.main: Concerns Over Social Media Link to Virginia Girl’s Killing
headline.print_headline: Concerns Over Social Media Link to Girl’s Killing

snippet: The arrest of two Virginia Tech students in the abduction and murder of a 13-year-old girl who posted on a Facebook group called Teen Dating and Flirting has set off fresh concerns about the dangers of young people who seek liaisons on social media.
